page.title: 11DALMENY'S WILDLIFE
page.content: The coastline between Cramomd Island and Hound Point has a rich variety of birdlife. Knots, redshanks, oystercatchers, curlews, bar-tailed Godwits, ducks and gulls are some of the species seen along the shoreline where they roost in autumn and winter. Lapwings use the area as a low tide roost in winter. The birds depend for their food on the vast numbers of invertebrate animals that live in the mud: worms, mussels and snails, as many as 100,000 per square metre. At present, birds and industry co-exist. However, reclamation or pollution of the mudflats are serious threats to the survival of these great flocks of birds.
